REPUBLIC OF SOUTH AFRICA
Case No

IN THE SUPREME COURT OF APPEAL
OF SOUTH AFRICA
In the matter of:
WESTERN CAPE EDUCATION DEPARTMENT
First Appellant
MINISTER OF EDUCATION
Second Appellant

HOWIE JA
:
Before October 1995 a legally married woman employed in
the public service whose husband was not permanently medically unfit for
paid employment was not entitled to the public service house owner
allowance. That was laid down by a provision in the Public Service Staff
Code and applied, by way of personnel administrative measures
promulgated by the Minister of Education, to teachers. This piece of
unwarranted discrimination notwithstanding, Karen George (to whom,
although she is no longer a party to the litigation, I shall refer as
"respondent") applied for the allowance. She is, and was at all material
times, a legally married teacher in the employ, in a permanent capacity,
of the two appellants, being the Western Cape Education Department
("the Department") and the Minister. But for her being married she
would have been entitled to the allowance.
The application was submitted in October 1994. The
Department refused it on the ground that she was married. In November

sections.facts: Karen Jean George, a married teacher employed permanently by the Western Cape Education Department and the Minister of Education, applied in October 1994 for the public service house‑owner allowance. At that time the Public Service Staff Code, as administered by the Minister of Education, excluded legally married women whose husbands were not permanently medically unfit from receiving the allowance. The Department refused her application on the basis of her marital status.
sections.issues: Whether the Department’s refusal to grant the house‑owner allowance to a married female teacher, on the basis of a statutory provision that differentiates on the basis of marital status, breaches the constitutional right to equality and constitutes unlawful discrimination.
sections.principles: The court must apply the constitutional guarantee of equality and non‑discrimination, interpreting the Public Service Staff Code and any administrative measures in a manner consistent with the Constitution. Administrative decisions must be lawful, reasonable and not arbitrarily discriminatory. Pre‑1995 provisions that singled out married women are subject to scrutiny under the equality clause.
sections.application: Applying the equality principle, the court finds that the provision denying the allowance to married women lacks a rational basis and discriminates on marital status without justification. The Department’s administrative rule, being an embodiment of this discriminatory provision, is therefore invalid to the extent that it contravenes constitutional norms. Consequently, the refusal to award the allowance to Ms George is unlawful.
sections.conclusion: The judgment sets aside the Department’s refusal and orders that the house‑owner allowance be granted to Karen Jean George. The discriminatory provision of the Public Service Staff Code is declared inconsistent with the Constitution, and the Department is directed to adjust its policy accordingly.
